title: 108_s2760
content: The Act may be cited as the "Public Safety Officers' Defense Act" and includes substantive limits. Section 2254 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include crimes against public safety officers. A court cannot consider any claim related to judgment or sentence unless it meets specific grounds for consideration. Any such application must be transferred to the appropriate district court for review. The amended Section 2254 of title 28, US Code, applies to habeas corpus applications for individuals in custody for crimes involving the killing of a public safety officer. Any such application must be authorized by a court of appeals panel before being considered by the district court. The time limits for habeas corpus applications for individuals in custody for crimes involving the killing of a public safety officer must be authorized by a court of appeals panel before being considered by the district court. Section 2254(j) of title 28, United States Code, as amended by this Act, now includes time limits for filing motions for an evidentiary hearing in the district court. Any motion must be filed within 90 days after the State files its answer, and the court must grant or deny the motion within 30 days after the opposing party files a pleading in opposition. The amended Section 2254(j) of title 28, United States Code sets time limits for filing motions for an evidentiary hearing in the district court. Any motion must be filed within 90 days after the State files its answer. The court must grant or deny the motion within 30 days after the opposing party files a pleading in opposition. Any evidentiary hearing must be convened within 60 days of the order and completed within 150 days. The district court must enter a final order on the application for a writ of habeas corpus within 15 months of the State filing its answer or within 60 days of the case being submitted for decision, whichever is earlier. The amended Section 2254(j) of title 28, United States Code sets time limits for filing motions for an evidentiary hearing in the district court. If the district court fails to comply, the State can petition the court of appeals for a writ of mandamus. The court of appeals must grant or deny the petition within 30 days. A timely filed notice of appeal from an order issuing a writ of habeas corpus stays the order pending appeal. The court of appeals must decide the appeal within a specified time frame. The amended Section 2254(j) of title 28, United States Code sets time limits for filing motions for an evidentiary hearing in the district court. Following a decision by a panel of the court of appeals, a petition for panel rehearing is not allowed. The court of appeals may grant rehearing en banc within 30 days of filing a petition. If granted, a final decision must be made within 120 days of the order. The court of appeals may grant rehearing en banc within 30 days of filing a petition. If granted, a final decision must be made within 120 days of the order. The order granting rehearing en banc is entered. If the court of appeals fails to comply with the requirements, the State may petition the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus. Time limits apply to initial applications, second or successive applications, redeterminations, and appeals following a remand for further proceedings. In proceedings following remand in the district court, time limits start from the date of the remand order if no further briefing is needed. If additional briefing is required, time limits begin from the date of a responsive brief or the due date if no timely brief is filed. In the court of appeals, time limits start from the date of the remand order if no further briefing is needed. If additional briefing is required, time limits begin from the date of a responsive brief or the due date if no timely brief is filed. Failure to comply with time limitations does not grant relief from a judgment of conviction or sentence, nor entitle a capital applicant to a stay of execution for the purpose of litigating any application or appeal. SEC. 4. APPLICATION TO PENDING CASES. The amendments made by this Act apply to cases pending on or after the date of enactment. Time limits in pending cases will run from the date of enactment if the event occurred before that date.
